resources.string: This app is intended to be used by parents in Vanuatu who have children that are less than a year old, in order to help them remember to get the proper vaccinations in their first year.

- Immunization is important: every child needs a series of immunizations during the first year of life\n - Immunization protects children against several dangerous diseases. A child who is not immunised is more likely to fall ill, become permanently disabled or undernourished and/or die\n - It is safe to immunize a child suffering from minor illnesses, disabilities and malnutrition
Would you like to take a picture of your child to use as their id picture?
Tuberculosis (TB) is caused by bacteria that attack the lungs, but it can also affect other parts of the body such as the bones, joints, and brain.
Hepatitis B is a serious disease caused by a virus that attacks the liver. The virus, which is called hepatitis B virus (HBV), can cause a lifelong infection, liver cancer, liver failure and death.
Target Disease: Hepatitis B, Haemophilus Influenza type B (HiB), Diptheria, Pertusis, and Tetanus

Hepatitis B is a serious disease caused by a virus that attacks the liver. The virus, which is called hepatitis B virus (HBV), can cause a lifelong infection, liver cancer, liver failure and death.
Haemophilus influenza type B (HiB) is bacteria that often causes pneumonia or meningitis and/or death in young children.
Diphtheria is a bacterium infecting the throat, which in turn affects breathing and swallowing that could be fatal. It can also affect the heart.
Tetanus bacteria make toxins that attack the nerves and cause muscles to become tense and stiff. The bacteria infect the body through dirty wounds or through the umbilicus following non-sterile delivery. People of all ages can get tetanus but the disease is particularly common and serious in newborn babies. This is called neonatal tetanus. Most infants who get this disease die.

Poliomyelitis, or polio, is a crippling disease caused by any one of three related viruses, poliovirus types 1, 2 or 3. Initial symptoms are fever, fatigue, headache, vomiting and stiffness in the neck and pain in the limbs. One in 200 infections leads to irreversible paralysis (usually in the legs). Among those paralysed, 5-10% die when their breathing muscles become immobilized.

Measles is a very contagious disease with symptoms of high fever and rash. Measles kills more children than any other preventable disease. Since the disease is exceptionally infectious, it tends to occur as an epidemic that may cause many deaths especially among malnourished children.
